content:
1, 2016
												You know what, this is a great game and I wish I played it more often than I do. It's one of those games that is ridiculously fun to play with people. The AI is boring and so therefore it's not a game to play with by yourself. With a group of friends, you guys will have a blast. There is a variety of game modes, such as a basketball like mode or a mode where you need to hang on to a certain ball for a certain amount of time first, but death match is just where the real fun and this game's strong point is. There is a lot of powerups, there is great player customization, and there is (for some reason) item drops you can use to sell, trade, or create cosmetic stuff with. No, I mean like legit actual items, like steam item drops. Weird for an obscure indie game to implement that feature, isn't it? Granted, 16 of my friends already have this game, so I suppose it isn't too obscure. Regardless, if you are looking for a game with some meat on it for a decent price even outside of a sale, you found it. The gameplay is fast paced, it's fun, it's simple, it's just good. There is only negative experiences I've had, such as people catching my shots from ridiculous distances from them, that I feel had more to do with connection issues (my friends are all ♥♥♥♥ing europeons for some reason, damn foriegners). However, I do notice the ball can still be caught even after hitting a wall or the ground, which I think is unfair and unnecessary. The game could have more content if the developer had the desire to add anymore I feel, but I think the asking price is still fair for what you're getting. So don't think to hesitate. 7/10Pros-Good fast & simple gameplayFairly unique take on the genreGood enough amount of varietyCons-I feel the game could have more content such as more maps and the likes, maybe even the ability for users to make their own maps.I feel sometimes that catching is ridiculous, especially when it has already hit the ground.AI sucks real hard and online isn't overwhelmingly active, you will need friends.

content:
8, 2016
												In most cases, you want someone who has a large number of hours playing a game to give a review. In the case of this game, that isn't needed. WIthing 10 hours, everybody knows if they like this game or not. Except that EVERYBODY loves this game. Play it once and you'll be addicted as you zoom around, dodging balls, making awesome throws, rocking out to music, and so much more. The game is constantly updated- an amazing task for such a simple game - and allows for there to be Workshop items to be constantly downloaded and used. Overall the game is great. But after a few games, you run into a problem-- very few people play this game as a whole, and they are further divided by location around the world. While this can put a damper on some round, when everybody leaves and you're stuck with some OP bots, it has its upsides. As you get to play more, you see certain players more often and start to build teams with random people and even learn play style. So, even with its faults, it is an amazing game, everyone should play at least once.--Edit--At just under 100 hours and climbing past level 78, I have seen the many changes of this game. The game itself is under constant renovation and is always adapting and evolving to meet the needs of its community. I am happy to sit for hours with my friends and play this amazingly simple game. While I do not play it as often as before, it will forever be in debt to this game for the many wonderful memories it has given me.

content:
, 2015
												I've played RRDDD for a little over 100 hours. I got it the week it came out. No matter what you say about it, you can't deny that it has improved a lot.Graphics:There exactly the right amount of detail on each map. Most of the graphics are on the walls, which is good. There's lights that flash to the music and every surface is textured. There are nice-looking particle effects and the graphics are all-round polished. There isn't an extraordinary amount of detail but I feel anything more wouldn't help the game at all and would end up being distracting.Audio:The music is great. Its techno tunes from a bunch of different artists. You can even add your own songs to the playlist and listen to those, or grab some from the workshop. The sound effects are great too. They’re all present and sound right.Gameplay:There are probably people better suited to review this. In my personal opinion, it’s really fun and engaging. There are a bunch of maps with a bunch of gamemodes. Gameplay is mostly skill based and competitive. I did of course find myself getting a bit frustrated sometimes, but that’s the case with any game.Features:-Good singleplayer and bots-Workshop support-Drops and crafting system-Cards and achievementsNegatives:-lag. A lot.

content:
y 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is one of the best first person multiplayer games I have ever played. Keep in mind I have played call of duty, Halo, Destiny, Titanfall, Team Fortress 2,the Counter strike series, and garry's mod. This is one of the best fps games because it is easy to learn to play and you can easily play it with freinds, easily customize matches, no extra places to spend money, as well as different modes to suit your play style that is both fun with yourself, but even better with friends. The Powerups this game has will also boost the fun level to new hights if you so choose to use it.Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball has an amazing soundtrack that you can listen to for hours and best of all you can have a balls to the wall match that has all the powerups in the game on all at once, that combonation makes for some pretty epic games. In conclusion this game is super fun, and the more people play, the more fun it gets. The price for this game is amazing if you want a great Fps that you can play with your friends and also play by yourself. There are also constant updates that make the game get better and better, this combined with a great dev that listens is a killing blow to garbage broken overpriced fps's that are basicaly rinse and repeat every year. I would buy this game again if I had to, but since I don't I'm going to go play it now!

content:
6, 2016
												This game, I don't know what to say. Not only is it a lot funner than actual dodgeball, it also has a bunch of different gamemodes to help customize the experience and change it a bit. I also love that there is online and local multiplayer. Personally I don't play too much online but I love the local muliplayer so I can play this game with my friends. And adding the workshop was great too. In fact, my favorite gamemode is from the workshop! So, it's just a really fun experience! It has a bunch of different modes, gear to customize your robot. Settings to edit each mode. Both online and local multiplayer. An arcade mode, and so much more! This is a lot to come out of an 8 dollar game. I'd probably buy it if it was 30 dollars! It just has so much content in it and of course, it's very fun to play. Easy 10/10. I will be playing this for quite a long time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Nothing feels so satisfying as doing a 360 spin mid-air and hitting your friend in the face with a dodgeball.  Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball is a great example of multiplayer arena games just being so dang fun.  It strikes a great balance between skill and chaos.  The disco part of this game gives it so much personality.  Music is used extremely well to keep the game exciting and fast paced.    Visuals keep improving, but the unique neon lights and dance club feeling are great.  As an Early Access game, it continually gets updates and improvements.  The dev is quite active in the game and any sites about the game.  You might even play him in a match!  I bought this much earlier and it has only improved from then.  However the only downside is that player base can be somewhat small.  This isn't a major problem because of AI but also because you're only in a room with 6-12 other people.  I recommend the 4-pack, or getting your friends to buy the game too.

content:
2
												FUN! BEATS! DODGEBALL!Seriously, though. Why isn't this game out there being played? Pros:
 With friends, it could be a lotta fun! The soundtrack is fitting.  Gameplay is very engaging. It's both casual and competitive. It's like one of those party games like SpeedRunners. Controls are simple and easy. What the game will really put to the test are your reflexes and aiming.  It's not a game you'd play for hours, but it's definitely one which you'd play to simply have fun for a while. And you'll find yourself coming back to it once a while. It's constantly found in indie bundles, so there's no reason to buy it as a standalone from the store.Cons:
 The multiplayer is a ghost town. There's no one around to play with! What the hell?! Why isn't this game well-known?! This is the primary feature of the game, and it's almost completely dead. It should've added some retro stuff like synthwave. It's completely dubstep and all, which can get kinda boring for people with music taste like mine.   The price isn't worth it, considering how the multiplayer is almost dead. Keep an eye for it in giveaways or bundles, though.Verdict: I really liked the game. I got this from a bundle, and it's not worth the full price, since the multiplayer was what I looked forward to. And it's constantly packed in bundles, so if you see it, don't hesitate to redeem it. You should give it a try. It's definitely a worthy party game.

												good thing I got this game in the humble bundle. I always wanted to play it but if feels completly awkward. I assume because of bad netcode. You get hit by balls not even remotly aimed to your direction and it stutters all the time (or is it slowmotion?). Even with the fix to force d3d9 it still feels out of place. This game needs better netcode and a way better tutorial (what is grinding and how do I do it in this movement system?). I really can't recommend the game. There are even arenas which are just 1 room with nothing to hide where this game becomes completly random. I wanted this game to be as fluid as rocket league but it feels completly wrong.(Played some singleplayer matches with bots some matches against players and bots mixed and some matches with only players)

content:
0, 2016
												Unfortunately despite the well easy mechanics for play and simplicity, the game lack of community is one that takes away from its well fun. Little community as is and half of the individuals care nothing for other players except themselfs or their own friends while leaving rooms an open thing. The game does NOT have language control and its job --or so it will or may say-- is it wants a strict and clean envoriment of players. Being told "Kindly get the ♥♥♥♥ out." Is not actually by definition of such.Secondly the issues is the game delay or lag is one that destroyes its multiplayer aspect. One moment you'll have a dodge ball to use, the second the ball SUDDENLY VANISHES cause the game delay or lag was supposed to give it to some one else. I've found despite my ping being the best or the worst, it has no valid communication between responsible lag handling and ruining stability of play cause of delay favortism.The third and final goes towards the AI. Yes, they are pleasently amazing. They jack up your skills. They enforce your ability of having to think, it is senseless fun to just throw the ball and get a hit or die.Why negative> Cause the AI are inhuman like *(Almost too Ai like) HOW, how are they TOO Ai like, their AI's!They will react almost with a 360 awareness of all times when the game forces you into a first person viewing. Idk. I can't see a player getting a ball, turning aorund with mid throw, then turning back around in just the same instant of motion with out flaw killing you. It's as if they knew on the dot where your at.> That's not a human possible thing to have happen. Not with out second hand guessing or pre-planning. These Ai's, have none of that.The game is sensless fun and I advise any one getting it to at least understand the negative probability you may encounter and over look it. I however, am slapping a no on this one.

content:
ber 5, 2016
												Wow.I thought this looked pretty fun when I watched Markiplier play it, but I was not prepared for the exhilaration this disco party had to offer.The title frankly couldn't be a better summary of the game itself; you're an acrobatic, rollerblade-wheeled robot playing a (team) game of free-range dodgeball in the most visually and audibly intense club ever concieved. Though you can adjust the graphical output, it'd be good to note that this game is probably not for people with rapid color change and light sensitivity, because every surface in each of the (I don't even know how many) stages is lined with neon. If that doesn't bother you and your video card is functioning well, then buckle in for this techno and bass adreneline rave.The gameplay is similar to an FPS, except that the fast-paced mechanics and "small" arena size render camping impossible, and instead of slowly lugging your limited stock of guns & ammo that you have to keep stock of and try to be covert with, you just grab any of of the dozen glowing orbs off the ground next to you and throw it. It's apparent that months upon months worth of time was put into the tweaking of the physics and controls, because I would say that from the jumping to the boosting to the seemingly excessive sliding when trying to stop, all the slight calibrations are built to this game's exact specifications. A great job is done of raising a fun and competitive air of tension that inspires to pick up a ball and peg your opponent straight back to their starting gate before they can do it to you.It also seems to me that much time was spent on the polish of this game, seeing as after playing for non-stop for multiple hours, I only encountered one or two minor bugs, and that was just a matter of my router acting up.This game is incredibly smooth and unexpectedly action packed; fun is just a bi-product that you can't help but get out of it.Like FPSs?Good at FPSs?Like dodgeball?Good at dodgeball?Do you like music you can feel the beat of from five rooms away?If you answered yes of no to any or all of the questions, ignore the questions you were just asked and buy yourself a couple hundred tickets to the Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball.PS: Happy 2am.PSS: I slightly shredded my throat yelling at...kinda eveything on screen, during the 3 hours I was playing today.

content:
er 9, 2016
												i5 4570;  Asus GTX 770; 2x4gb ddr3; Win10Purchased as a bundle $5.00 CAD; Bundle Stars, Indie Legends 5 (8 games).This game plays out like Unreal, Quake, Rune and the other arena-type fps games.  Use turbo-boost to jump, slide and grab the ball before your opponent and either throw it at them or use it to score (ala basketball).Kill streaks, combos, and strobing lights and bumping techo music.Plays flawless and is fast enough to keep you and 3 friends entertained for a few hours maybe longer.  I like how it plays as "robots on scooters", so jumping and timing is needed, but the game is arcade enough to be lenient.  You can tweek the game substatially (no gravity, big heads, infinite speedboost etc etc ETC).Simple.  Plays fast.  Lenient.  Bumping techno beats.  Happy faces, sunglasses, and hats.

content:
er 7, 2016
												Saw this game on sale for a cheap two bucks and thought to myself "what's the worst that could happen?". Apparently not  very much because this game is simply amazing. Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball is a crazy name for a crazy game that's crazy fun!Pros: Fast paced action-packed arena insta-gib shooter; the pace at which this game plays is incredibly fast and will get your heart pumping. Rewarding mechanics; favoring client actions over those of the server. If you see a hit on your screen, it's a hit. Beautifully optimized; my computer is a complete potato and almost every map easily warrants me a happy 50-60 FPS. Fun to play with friends; start up a private match with a couple friends and have a blast. Or plug in a few controllers and engage in split-screen multiplayer. Unbelievably friendly community; in other multiplayer shooters the most interaction from other players is getting cussed out for 10 minutes. In this game everyone is incredibly welcoming and won't hesitate to strike up a conversation about whatever. People simply laugh off a lucky shot, or give you kudos for something spectacular rather than calling you a cheater, or other expletive. Light hearted concept makes it a great family title; if you're interested in playing with the family, this is a great multiplayer title to do so. I mean, come on. It's dodgeball. It's just a damned blast to play. It's hard to be mad at a game like this. Just enough edge to make it feel competitive, but just enough fun to keep you from being salty. The perfect balance.Cons: Sometimes the servers are a bit empty. It's not horrible, but isn't optimal either. I hate to judge a game by the amount of players it has, but sometimes it's a neccecary evil. Occasional bugs here and there, but this is to be expected from an indie game. The developer makes up for it with lightning-fast responses to bug reports on the forums. Looks like he reads every one as well. I have to play devil's advocate a bit with this one. The aforementioned hit registration can be a blessing, it feels great on your end, making sure every hit counts, but when playing against someone with a poor connection it can feel like a curse. A ball that flies way past you might hit you, or you might get hit even if you duck behind cover. There is no perfect system and this game has it at a balance where it's about as good as it can get. Just one of the pitfalls of online gaming. You're not playing it. What a con to a wonderful game! It's only $10 bucks for this spectacular title, and even better on sale. Why not give it a try? If you hate every moment of it Steam allows you to refund a game as long as you haven't played more than two hours, so there's hardly anything to lose.
